Title: Carly & Cam's 5k a day for 31 days!

Description:
I want to be able to raise money for our brothers and sisters in Yemen 

The people of Yemen are on the verge of ascending upon you as if they are clouds. They are the best (people) on Earth.

This is a personal thing for me as I come from a Bangladeshi/Yemeni background and I feel like it’s an obligation for me to raise money for this cause. As this is the first time for me to be doing something like this I would LOVE the help of MY brothers and sisters in Islam to help them. We are ONE ummah and how would you feel knowing that there’s no help and you are watching your children die in front of you because YOU aren’t able to feed YOUR children?

I ask Allah to help us to bring their hearts over to His obedience and relieve them of their burdens.

I want to ask you some questions:
1. Would you buy medicine for your children and go without food tomorrow?
2. Would you as an individual beg for people’s leftovers knowing that YOU won’t be able to eat again?
3. Would you let YOUR child miss school because YOU couldn’t find food for the family?

Unfortunately they don’t have a choice to do otherwise and THIS is the REALITY of the families in Yemen right now.

So I ask as your sister in Islam to help our brothers and sisters of Yemen.

May Allah accept your donations and I wish you all the highest rank of Jannah. Ameen.

Love and thanks from Najifa Uddin.
Title: Najifa's Yemen Emergency Appeal

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Lambeth Books' JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving. They'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate, saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

We have recently set up Lambeth Books as an imprint for local and new writing and a big part of it is to bring attention to inner city life and celebrate its attractions as much as highlight its deficiencies. So Lambeth Books came up with the great idea of creating a virtual book donor bank. The books will never exist, but the money will. And to track our fundraising we came up with a further idea to keep a count of the donations made through Lambeth Books' JustGiving page for Baranrdo's with a Lambeth Books' bookometer. Every three months we will calculate the amount of books donated by dividing the amount raised in that quarter by the average price of a book in the UK to calculate how many 'virtual' books we have managed to collect on behalf of Barnardo's. And maybe just maybe we could collect enough to give vulnerable children in the UK each a book to read.

Fundamentally Lambeth Books doesn't believe in the need for charity. We believe we should live in a world where charity is not necessary but in these times childrens' needs transcend such cerebral ambitions. If we can help children in their time of trouble our ethics go out the window. Hence this fundraising page. We set the fund going with a contribution, the rest is up to you.
Title: Lambeth Books' virtual book donor bank

Description:
Gracie wanted to do something for a food bank during lockdown so she has decided to do a sponsored bounce for the Trussell Trust so that "people don't get hungry."

Every £10 raised could help give a parent peace of mind that their family will not go hungry tonight.

£2.50 provides the ingredients and materials for one person to attend an Eat Well Spend Less course.

£5 could help to provide a secure environment in which people can discuss their problems freely and openly.

£10 could also help to provide fuel for one of our vans to transport food from our Warehouses to our Foodbank Centres.

£20 could help support someone take their first steps out of poverty.

From the Chief Exec of the Trussell Trust, Emma Revie,:

"As a nation we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute – illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job could happen to any of us, and we owe it to each other to make sure sufficient financial support is in place when we need it most.

It’s hard to break free from hunger if there isn’t enough money coming in to cover the rising cost of absolute essentials like food and housing. For too many people staying above water is a daily struggle. It’s completely unacceptable that anyone is forced to turn to a food bank as a result."

With your help #ThisCanChange
Title: Gracie's Trampoline Jump For The Trussell Trust on Thursday 11th June 2020

Create Your Own Zoo challenge

All you need to do is donate £5 on the JustGiving page, then send a picture of your entry with as much detail as possible to Laura Pearson by Monday 15th June and Dave Paterson will just the best zoo.

Bringing up children and raising a healthy, happy family is hard work at the best of times. When a child is born with or develops a terminal condition, the emotional and physical impact affects the whole family and can be overwhelming. At Demelza, we focus on supporting each child, young person and family we work with to achieve the best possible life. Description:
At this extremely challenging and difficult time for everyone, the Cornish Seal Sanctuary are increasingly fearful over how they will be able to continue to care for their amazing resident animals, especially with the necessary extension of the Coronavirus related lockdown in the UK.

It costs the charity £23,000 a month for their dedicated animal care team to feed, provide daily care, vital medicines and equipment to the Sanctuary's residents. 

With the Sanctuary being closed at this time, the loss of income from visitors is proving detrimental to our charity.

In these difficult and uncertain times, the Sanctuary needs to raise £23,000 which would help to cover a months worth of food, daily care, essential medicines and equipment for their resident animals. This would be an enormous help to the Sanctuary to continue looking after the animals in their care. 

A donation of any size would go such a long way. Thank you for your generous support!

The word yoga comes from Sanskrit and means to unite or join. Though we may be physically distant from one another at this time , we can still join together as a yoga community to celebrate the joy of yoga by participating in these sessions.

Description:
Many in our society were already at breaking point before the coronavirus pandemic. Covid-19 has swept many more of us into poverty. Due to this crisis our drop off points have closed and consequently public donations of hygiene products have decreased significantly.

Galvanised by the belief that being clean is not a luxury or a privilege, The Hygiene Bank Medway is a local branch of a registered, people powered, grassroots charity grounded in community. We collect and re-distribute donated toiletries, hygiene, beauty and personal care items to Medway charities, voluntary organisations and schools. These in turn are then given for free to their beneficiaries. Our passion stems from a sense of injustice: it's not right that anyone should face hygiene poverty in modern Britain.  

We are a self funded project and if you are able to support us and those we work with all donations are very gratefully received and will eable us to continue the great work we are doing across Medway.

90p in every pound of your donation to this Justgiving campaign will be used to directly purchase much need hygiene products. These will be sent to our local community partners that include Home-start Medway, Medway Foodbank, All Saints Community Project, Age UK Medway plus time numerous families via our growing schools partnership!

Description:
We are a team of seven 10 and 11 year-olds who want to help make a difference to children struggling in our community as a result of their lives being turned upside down by Coronavirus. 

We have heard of the challenges local children and families are facing as a result of the lockdown and not being able to go to school. 

Many families are struggling to buy food and although Free School Meal vouchers are supposed to be available, these are taking a long time to process and only cover a small amount towards children’s lunches. Some of our local schools have nearly 50% of their pupils receiving free school lunches so this affects a large number of families. Some schools have set up food banks to help these families – often funded from the pockets of the school staff.

Many families are also struggling to support the continued education of their children as online access is often limited by the broadband available and the number of devices in the home.

We want to raise money to help those in our local community who are experiencing food insecurity. We also want to help where we can with the digital divide, to ensure that the children who can’t currently access their lessons can continue with their education.

We have committed to run a total of 289 km, as a team over 28 days. The distance of 289 km represents a ‘virtual’ route covering all 40 Acute Care London hospitals from Hillingdon Hospital to Royal Marsden Hospital.  

Each of us has committed to run 1.5km (separately) every day for 28 consecutive days, a combined daily distance of 10.5 km. We started running on 11th May and are due to finish on 7th June.

We are pupils at Kensington Prep School in Fulham and we’re raising money with our school registered fundraising charity and all monies raised will be distributed directly to families in need and their schools, liaising with the local school network of Head Teachers
Title: RUN289 - 7 GIRLS - 40 HOSPITALS - 289 KILOMETERS

As a team we are going to be raising funds for MHUK by completing individual walking, running and cycling challenges. Getting fit while also fund raising for a charity that is close to the hearts of lots of our colleagues.

Why the title MHUK 16000? MHUK has been running for 40 years and we have approximately 400 colleagues across our Area that can participate in one way or other. Times the 2 together and you get 16000!! Our aim is to complete 16000km as a team.

Description:
While ticketed gardens have been allowed to open this week, Chester Zoo has been told by the government that it must stay closed indefinitely. 

While they have managed so far, feeding all their animals without the support of tickets sales is proving unmanageable. We will be continuing to support the zoo with our memberships while it is closed, but Elliott wanted to do more.

Elliott is going to use his pocket money to buy the ingredients for his elephant ear cookies, while Mum will provide the stamps and packaging. (For reference: if Elliott reaches his goal I calculate that he will have donated about a month’s worth of pocket money.)

For every £5 donated Elliott will send you a box of ten elephant ear cookies, and a donation of £10 will receive A box of twenty-five cookies. 

We can also post them to your friends to spread the love!

So can you help Elliott to save Chester Zoo?

——————————————————————

The gates may be closed, but Chester Zoo is still doing all it can to prevent extinction. From conservation at the zoo with 35,000 animals, to helping wildlife organisations across the world to manage the impact of this global crisis, Chester Zoo is determined not to let coronavirus stand in the way of its vital mission. At such a time of crisis and uncertainty for everyone, I have chosen to raise funds for Chester Zoo so they can use it where they need it most and continue to make their mission of preventing extinction a reality and ensure the survival of species for the future.Together, we can act for wildlife!
Title: Elliotts Elephant Ears for Elephants!

Description:
Welcome to the Class 4W at Laxton Junior School fundraising page. As we are all working from home at present one of the things that helps us with our mindfulness during these difficult times is getting closer to nature. So, we and some of the other classes in our school, have been growing sunflowers which has been great fun We are going to see who can grow the tallest! 

Now some of us have grown more than one, including our teacher, Mr Worthington, and we wondered what to do with them all. Mr W thought it would be a good idea to have little plant sales in our own communities to raise a few pounds for our local food bank, the Stamford and Oundle Food Bank. They are part of the Trussell Trust, who's aim is to end hunger and poverty in the UK.

The Trussell Trust support a nationwide network of food banks which together provide emergency food and support to people locked in poverty, and campaign for change to end the need for food banks in the UK.

In the UK, more than 14 million people are living in poverty – including 4.5 million children. They support more than 1,200 food bank centres in the UK to provide a minimum of three days’ nutritionally-balanced emergency food to people who have been referred in crisis, as well as support to help people resolve the crises they face. Between April 2018 and March 2019, food banks in our network provided a record 1.6 million food supplies to people in crisis, a 19% increase on the previous year.

It takes more than food to end hunger. That’s why they bring together the experiences of food banks in the network to challenge the structural economic issues that lock people in poverty, and campaign to end the need for food banks in the UK.

So, if you would like to join in the fun and grow some plants to sell for a few pennies each then please do so, donating any monies raised to this fund-raising page. If you would just like to make a small donation then any contributions will be gratefully received as we aim to raise £250 for this very worthwhile charity.

Happy growing!
Title: 4W are Growing Plants for Food!

Description:
My son and I will be running a combined total of 400 miles in 40 days starting from 01-May-2020 to 09-Jun-2020. We all can do our part to make a difference however big or small.

More and more people are being forced to use food banks because they cannot afford the basics in life. Last year, food banks in the Trussell Trusts network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food parcels to people in crisis, with over 500,000 of these going to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year.Now, as the Coronavirus pandemic develops, it's likely that increasing numbers of people will need support from their local food bank. As food bank staff and volunteers work to source and distribute food to people who need support, their resources are becoming increasingly stretched as they come under additional pressure.Were working closely with our network of over 1,200 food banks to work out how we can best support each food bank in the coming months to make sure that they're able to continue to help people in crisis in their local communities.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Employees of TMI Foods will be taking on the One Million Steps Challenge to raise money for NHS Charities Together. The challenge is to each take One Million Steps over a 3 month period, starting on the 1st June and ending on the 31st August.

NHS Charities Together launched the COVID-19 urgent appeal in March this year to help support NHS staff and volunteers caring for COVID-19 patients.

The money raised will be used to meet the immediate and urgent needs of staff, volunteers and patients - providing somewhere comfortable so they can take a break, nutritious food and drink, use of electronic tablets so patients, staff and volunteers can stay in touch with loved ones, counselling support to protect mental health and help staff and volunteers process what they are dealing with.

Thank you
Title: TMI Foods - 1 Million Steps Challenge

Description:
Waitrose & Partners Food magazine is raising money for its charity partner, the Trussell Trust, which supports food banks across the UK. It is one of several charities chosen by Waitrose & Partners to receive extra support during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Donate today, and you could also be in with a chance of winning one of the beautiful artworks in our illustrated July issue. Many of the renowned British artists featured, including Charlie Mackesy and Chris Riddell, have agreed to donate either their original artwork or an exclusive signed print to help us raise money.

After donating on this page, simply enter our free prize draw at www.waitrose.com/winart to fill in your details and choose which artwork you’d like to win.

Donating £10 will give a parent peace of mind that their family will not go hungry this week. £20 could help support someone take their first steps out of poverty. And £50 will help offer people a place to turn to in times of crisis.

The prize draw opens on Tuesday 23 June and the deadline is midnight on Thursday 30 July. Find the full terms and conditions at www.waitrose.com/winart

The available artworks are listed below (and pictured above):

  1.  Charlie Mackesy – original rainbow cake illustration.
  2.  Alan Kitching – signed print of Paris Parsnip, as featured on page 38.
  3.  Joël Penkman – signed print of Ice Cream 1.
  4.  Henrietta Graham – signed print of her portrait of Calum Franklin.
  5.  Kate Jenkins – original knitted bagel.
  6.  Noma Bar – signed print of Positive Cooking, as featured on page 43.
  7.  Chris Riddell – original illustration, as featured on pages 44-45.
Title: Art with heart

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit.

The team in Gleeds Southampton are going to run/walk/swim/row/SUP/cycle as far as we possibly can during the summer of 2020 to raise money for LifeHouse (http://www.lifehouse.org.uk/). 

The Life House is a not-for-profit charity which is a Soup Kitchen and support centre for the homeless and those in need living in Portsmouth and Southsea.

We provide food, hot meals, clothing, counselling and general advice to vulnerable men and women and target the issues of homelessness and addiction locally.

We aim to create an environment of compassion and care, where people feel they belong, are accepted; and where they can build a sense of self-worth and confidence – a place where we can be generous with our time, energy and practical resources; where we can go the extra mile.

The Life House is a converted building which we have outgrown over the years. This means we are limited to the amount of service users that can be seated at any  one seating for the hot meals we provide. We have to ask out service used to queue up outside in the wind and rain and limit the time they can sit and have a rest bite from the elements.

Our intention is to expand so we can accommodate more service users at any one time. The building works we are raising money for will incorporate expanding in to the neighbouring church so we can sit more service users for hot meals. We plans to increase the capacity of the existing kitchen and make it more operationally efficient to help free up volunteers for they can focus on helping the service users.  

We would also like to expand to offer more services such as online training, expand our counselling service, hair dressing, and other wellbeing services such as, podiatry and medical advice etc.
Title: Gleeds 2020 Challenge

Description:
The mission of the Felix Project is simple - to take surplus food from their suppliers and deliver it to any charity that helps feed people. It's all nutritious and would otherwise go to waste. Not only that, but it helps fight food poverty and reduces costs for hardworking organisations.

A team across RWC are setting ourselves the challenge of running 150k each during the month of June.  This is the equivalent of 5k a day, every day for the 30 days.  The walkers amongst us have set ourselves the walking challenge and the injured have set ourselves challenges in line with doctor’s orders. 

Thank you for taking the time to visit our site and we would really appreciate anything you can give. All donations will be double-matched by our employer, RWC Partners, and some of it's employees, effectively tripling your contribution!
Title: RWC Team's June Challenge
